occurrences.line_text: Tho him she brought abord, and her swift bote
She turnd her bote about, and from them rowed quite.
For being fled into the fishers bote,
Which with rare light his bote did beautifie,
And comming to that Fishers wandring bote,
Yet without ship or bote her thence to row,
Said then the Boteman, Palmer stere aright,
And fortune Boteswaine no assuraunce knowes,
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
Them both together laid, to ioy in vaine delight.
The Dwarfe him brought his steed: so both away do fly.
Soone meete they both, both fell and furious,
Soone meete they both, both fell and furious,
Astonied both, stand sencelesse as a blocke,
Both staring fierce, and holding idely
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
And twixt them both was borne the bloudy bold Sans loy.
Hauing both found a new friend you to aid,
Both which fraile men do oftentimes mistake,
So both to battell fierce arraunged arre,
Both seemde to win, and both seemde won to bee,
Both seemde to win, and both seemde won to bee,
Still when she slept, he kept both watch and ward,
She found them both in darkesome corner pent;
And when they both had wept and wayld their fill,
Both day and night, of each degree and place,
But both from backe and belly still did spare,
So been they parted both, with harts on edge,
Feasting and courting both in bowre and hall;
Where both do fight alike, to win or yield?
The warlike feates of both those knights to see.
Both those the lawrell girlonds to the victor dew.
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
With hideous horrour both together smight,
Both charet swift and huntsman ouercast.
The wrath of thundring Ioue, that rules both night and day?
Great paines, & greater praise, both neuer to be donne.
The Antelope, and Wolfe both fierce and fell;
These eyes did see that knight both liuing and eke ded.
Both breathing vengeaunce, both of wrathfull hew:
Both breathing vengeaunce, both of wrathfull hew:
Therewith they gan, both furious and fell,
That with their force they perst both plate and maile,
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
Both hungred after death: both chose to win, or die.
Til breathlesse both them selues aside retire,
They both deformed, scarsely could be known.
Both carelesse of his health, and of his fame:
Both glorious brightnesse, and great terrour bred;
Both shield, and sword, and armour all he wrought
Both loftie towres and highest trees hath rent,
Which is through rage more strong then both were erst;
And guide his wearie gate both too and fro:
Both feet and face one way are wont to lead.
For both the lignage and the certain Sire,
In all affaires, and was both bold and free,
But all the good is Gods, both power and eke will.
Both plaine, and pleasant to be walked in,
And entertaynd them both, as best became,
A booke, that was both signd and seald with blood,
Ye both forwearied be: therefore a whyle
And made him pray both earely and eke late:
To be both gratious, and eke liberall:
That to their heauenly spouse both sweet and braue
Forth to an hill, that was both steepe and hy;
All were his earthly eyen both blunt and bad,
Then thou thy selfe, that was both borne and bred
A litle path, that was both steepe and long,
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
Both horse and man vp lightly rose againe,
Snatcht vp both horse & man, to beare them quite away.
Both Silo this, and Iordan did excell,
Both good and ill: O mornefull memory:
Both daughter and eke kingdome, lo I yield to thee.
And sacred pledges he both gaue, and had,
They bene ymet, both readie to affrap,
So bene they both attone, and doen vpreare
So courteous conge both did giue and take,
Besides them both, vpon the soiled gras
Betwixt them both can measure out a meane,
Thrise happie man, who fares them both atweene:
But both alike, when death hath both supprest,
But both alike, when death hath both supprest,
So both agree their bodies to engraue;
And both against the middest meant to worken woe.
Both knights and Ladies forth right angry far'd,
But they him spying, both with greedy forse
She scorning both their spights, does make wide way,
Does ride on both their backs, & faire her selfe doth saue.
Betweene them both, by conduct of his blade.
Her lowd gainsaid, and both their champions bad
And stablish termes betwixt both their requests,
But that their natures bad appeard in both:
For both did at their second sister grutch,
Betwixt them both the faire Medina sate
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
And both his foen with equall foyle to daunt.
They both nigh were, and each bad other flie:
Both fled attonce, ne euer backe returned eie.
Yet both doe striue their fearfulnesse to faine.
Both feare and hope he in her face did find,
And both her hands fast bound vnto a stake,
And both his hands fast bound behind his backe,
And both his feet in fetters to an yron racke.
Had both distaind her honorable blood,
Betwixt vs both, to counsell me the best.
I meant to purge both with a third mischiefe,
Betwixt them both, they haue me doen to dye,
The brother of Cymochles, both which arre
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
Whose bounty more then might, yet both he wondered.
Both loosers lot, and victours prayse alsoe.
Both Guyon and Pyrrochles: th'one (said shee)
So both together fiers engrasped bee,
Yet vertue vauntes in both their victories,
And both from rocks and flats it selfe could wisely saue.
Both what she was, and what that vsage ment,
Both slow and swift a like do serue my tourne,
Both of them high attonce their hands enhaunst,
And both attonce their huge blowes downe did sway;
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
The other both from drowning for to saue,
But realmes and rulers thou doest both confound,
And both did gnash their teeth, & both did threaten life.
And both did gnash their teeth, & both did threaten life.
Betwixt them both was but a litle stride,
Here Sleep, there Richesse, & Hel-gate the[m] both betwext.
Both roofe, and floore, and wals were all of gold,
Yet had both life and sence, and well could weld
But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom,
But both the fruit from hand, and floud from mouth
But both his hands most filthy feculent,
That vitall powres gan wexe both weake and wan,
Well knew they both his person, sith of late
Both fiercely bent to haue him disaraid;
That both eftsoones vpstarted furiously,
So both attonce him charge on either side,
Them both attonce compeld with courage bold,
And though they both stood stiffe, yet could not both withstond.
And though they both stood stiffe, yet could not both withstond.
Then is mans body both for powre and forme,
Behold, who list, both one and other in this place.
And Guyon his lost shield, they both yfere
Shewing her selfe both wise and liberall:
And twixt them both a quadrate was the base,
Both guestes and meate, when euer in they came,
As him the Steward bad. They both attone
That his disciples both desir'd to bee;
For he remembred both their infancies:
Whereat they burning both with feruent fire,
But both her selfe, and eke her daughter deare,
But Ebranck salued both their infamies
The second Brute, the second both in name,
Then gan the bloudie brethren both to raine:
Then Ruddoc and proud Stater, both allyes,
And left two sonnes, of pearelesse prowesse both;
And of them both did foy and tribute raise,
Those yet of her be Mertia[n] lawes both nam'd & thought.
Both in his armes, and crowne, and by that draught
And both of them men of renowmed might;
And braue ensample, both of martiall,
So to the riuers side they both together far'd.
And both as swift on foot, as chased Stags;
Againe through both the sides he strooke him quight,
Both of their life, and fame for euer fowly blent.
Both faire and fruitfull, and the ground dispred
For twixt them both the narrow way doth ly.
That twixt them both a pleasaunt port they made,
Both firmely armd for euery hard assay,
So diff'ring both in willes, agreed in fine:
Where both awhile would couered remaine,
Then suddeinly both would themselues vnhele,
That earst was sought to decke both bed and bowre,
They tooke them both, & both them strongly bound
They tooke them both, & both them strongly bound
They with them led, both sorrowfull and sad:
They bene ymet, and both their points arriued,
That seem'd both shield & plate it would haue riued;
Through thicke and thin, both ouer banke and bush
Dauncing and reueling both day and night,
You and your countrey both I wish welfare,
And honour both; for each of other worthy are.
Both leafe and fruit, both too vntimely shed,
Both leafe and fruit, both too vntimely shed,
Both loue and louer, without hope of ioy,
They both vprose and tooke their readie way
Forthwith themselues disguising both in straunge
Both Sunne and Moone, and make them him obay:
Long time ye both in armes shall beare great sway,
Till both the sonnes of Edwin he haue slaine,
Both slaine in battell vpon Layburne plaine,
Both ioynt partakers of the fatall paine:
Both for his griefe, and for her peoples sake,
Yet shall a third both these, and thine subdew;
They both conceiuing hope of comfort glad,
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
Both speare & shield of great powre, for her purpose fit.
How can they other do, sith both are bold and blind?
Both coosen passions of distroubled spright,
Eftsoones both flowres and girlonds farre away
Good both for earthly med'cine, and for heauenly food.
Thicke forest, was bescratcht, & both his feet nigh lame.
And fro me reft both life and light attone.
A forrest bill, which both his hands did straine;
That both his sides were thrilled with the throw,
But both attonce on both sides him bestad,
But both attonce on both sides him bestad,
But both of comfort him thou shalt depriue,
It left, but both did quite drye vp, and blast;
And to your willes both royalties and Realmes
And both encreast the prayse of woman kind,
And both encreast her beautie excellent;
She sweetly heard complaine, both how and what
We both are bound to follow heauens beheasts,
To seeke the fugitiue, both farre and nere,
Lucinaes aide: which when they both perceiued,
At last they both agreed, her seeming grieued
By which both in and out men moten pas;
Beates downe both leaues and buds without regard,
Continuall, both meeting at one time:
For both the boughes doe laughing blossomes beare,
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
Such laesinesse both lewd and poore attonce him made.
So both at her, and each at other wondered.
That their faire guest was gone, they both begonne
For both to be and seeme to him was labour lich.
In fleshly lust were mingled both yfere,
Turne we our steedes, that both in equall tilt
This said, they both a furlongs mountenance
She struggled strongly both with foot and hand,
But she both offers and the offerer
Both by the burning hart, which on his brest
Both light of heauen, and strength of men relate:
Both shew their auncestrie.
The which to him both far vnequall yeares,
And so defide them each, and so defide them both.
Both were full loth to leaue that needfull tent,
And both full loth in darkenesse to debate;
Yet both full liefe him lodging to haue lent,
And both full liefe his boasting to abate;
Confounds both land & seas, and skyes doth ouercast.
They rudely droue to ground both man and horse,
But after when both nations gan to striue,
Both first and second Troy shall dare to equalise.
Faire Lincolne, both renowmed far away,
Betwixt vs both vnknowne. So ended Paridell.
And Hellenors both eyes did eke beguyle,
Both eyes and hart attonce, during the whyle
It pleased well. So well they both agree;
Both was he loth to loose his loued Dame,
Yet sith he n'ote saue both, he sau'd that same,
To seeke her endlong, both by sea and lond.
I tread in dust thee and thy money both,
He ran as fast, as both his feete could beare,
Hatefull both to him selfe, and euery wight;
They after both, and boldly bad him bace,
But he them both outran a wondrous space,
They searched diuersely, so both diuided were.
Both with great ruth and terrour she was smit,
So forth they both yfere make their progresse,
Yet both are of thy haplesse hand extinct,
Yet both in flowres do liue, and loue thee beare,
Both for those two, and for his owne deare sonne,
Twixt both his hands few sparkes he close did straine,
In secret shade, and saw both first and last,
She cast to vse, both fit for hard emprize;
Saue that same woefull Ladie, both whose hands
With her owne trusty Squire, both full of feare,
And with great glorie both the shield of loue,
And maske her wounded mind, both did and sayd
But either he should neither of them haue, or both.
So foorth they went, and both together giusted;
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
They both vprose, and to their waies them dight:
And both the parts did speake, and both contended;
And both the parts did speake, and both contended;
And both misplast; that when th'one forward yode,
Both for his worth, that all men did adore,
So fell those two in spight of both their prydes,
Both foolish knights, I can but laugh at both,
Both foolish knights, I can but laugh at both,
Whilest both you here with many a cursed oth,
Both they vnwise, and warelesse of the euill,
Did beare them both to fell auenges end,
That both their speares with pitilesse remorse,
Where lying still a while, both did forget
At length they both vpstarted in amaze;
And drawing both their swords with rage extreme,
That both resolu'd the last extremities to proue.
Who seeing both bent to so bloudy games,
And both of old well knowing by their names,
Both greedie fiers on other to be wroken.
That seeke perforce her from you both to take,
Vnmindfull both of that discordfull crew,
And turne both him and her to honour in this wise.
But speare and curtaxe both vsd Priamond in field.
That both their liues may likewise be annext
A trompet blew; they both together met,
But they were both so watchfull and well eyde,
With that they both together fiercely met,
And with their axes both so sorely bet,
Both falling out doe stirre vp strifefull broyle,
Yet victors both them selues alwayes esteemed.
Then life and labour both in vaine to spend.
In th'arm-pit full, that through both sides the wound appeard.
So both at once fell dead vpon the field,
All suddenly they both vpstarted light,
Desirous both to haue the battell donne;
So wearie both of fighting had their fill,
Thereat the Champions both stood still a space,
And both were with one oliue garland crownd,
And eft them turned both againe to fight;
Those warlike champions both together chose,
The cause of both, of both their minds depends;
The cause of both, of both their minds depends;
And th'end of both likewise of both their ends.
And th'end of both likewise of both their ends.
Sent forth their Squire to haue them both descride,
That both were bent t'auenge his vsage base,
That we may vs reserue both fresh and strong,
So furiously they both together met,
That both rebutted, tumble on the plaine:
Where in a maze they both did long remaine,
That forcibly to ground they both together went.
Both in remembrance of his friends late harme,
So both together giue a new allarme,
And much repynd, that both of victors meede,
And at them both Sir Paridell did loure.
After so long a trauell, which them both did tire.
Both equall paines and equall perill shared:
Both Scudamour and Arthegall
So both to wreake their wrathes on Britomart agreed.
That to the ground she smote both horse and man;
Or both of them did thinke, obedience
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
We trauelled, both wearie of the way
And dayly feasting both in bowre and hall,
Both of the way, and warlike exercise,
Both through a forest ryding did deuise
And downe both sides two wide long eares did glow,
Both grace and gaine; but he in hell doth lie,
Both sire, and friends, and all for euer to forego.
And laying both his hands vpon his glaue,
That in her wrath she thought them both haue thrild,
That both his iuell he had lost so light,
Both in full sad and sorrowfull estate;
Tho when they both recouered were right well,
And eke his caue, in which they both were bond:
And on his warlike beast them both did beare,
The Ladies both on horse, together fast embraced.
Both for great feeblesse, which did oft assay
Therewith both Squire and dwarfe did tomble downe
But faithfull friendship doth them both suppresse,
And Placidas, they both vnto him ran,
That faire Poeana them beholding both,
Gan both enuy, and bitterly to ban;
To see the sight perforce, that both her eyes were loth.
She, though full oft she both of them had seene
But grieued was for losse both of her sire,
And eke of Lordship, with both land and fee:
Where she had them both shamefully fordonne,
At Scudamour, both his professed fone.
Both of their publicke praise had them despoyled,
Wherein the honor both of Armes ye shame,
And that both shield and she whom I behold,
Or that in Cyprus, both long since this same,
And flancked both the bridges sides along,
But I them both with equall hap defeated:
Both strongly arm'd, as fearing one another;
Yet were they brethren both of halfe the blood,
Nathlesse that Dame so well them tempred both,
They both her twins, both borne of heauenly seed,
They both her twins, both borne of heauenly seed,
And both her feete and legs together twyned
But for, they say, she hath both kinds in one,
Both male and female, both vnder one name:
Both male and female, both vnder one name:
Both linckt together neuer to dispart,
Both gifts of God not gotten but from thence,
Both girlonds of his Saints against their foes offence.
So both agreed, that this their bridale feast
To which they all repayr'd, both most and least,
Neleus and Pelias louely brethren both;
Which afterward both sea and land possest:
Ioy to you both, ye double noursery
But both him honor'd as their principall,
Through both whose borders swiftly downe it glides,
And Clare, and Harwitch both doth beautify:
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
Of Scots and English both, that tyned on his strand.
And both behind vpheld her spredding traine;
Both clad in colours like, and like array,
The Doune & eke the Frith, both which prepard her way.
Gainst one that hath both wronged you, and vs:
That both to good and bad he dealeth right,
There she him taught to weigh both right and wrong
So did the Ladies both, as may be knowne,
And left me here, both his & mine owne loue to morne.
Thereto they both did franckly condiscend,
And to his doome with listfull eares did both attend.
Sith then (sayd he) ye both the dead deny,
And both the liuing Lady claime your right,
Let both the dead and liuing equally
That is both swift and dangerous deepe withall;
And either both them drownes, or trayterously slaies.
Ne was Sir Artegall behinde: so both
There being both together in the floud,
For both were skild in that experiment,
And both in armes well traind and throughly tride.
And then together doe them both compare.
They both together ioyned might and maine,
Both her and eke all others to excell:
Both darting forth faire beames to each mans eye,
And both adorn'd with lampes of flaming light,
Of both their beauties to make paragone,
Streight way so soone as both together met,
Both brethren, whom one wombe together bore,
So stood they both in readinesse thereby,
Both goodly portions, but of both the better she.
Both goodly portions, but of both the better she.
Both Amidas and Philtra were displeased:
With both his hands behinde him pinnoed hard,
And beare with you both wine and iuncates fit,
And earely calling forth both man and beast,
With bitter strokes it both began, and ended.
Thinking at once both head and helmet to haue raced.
That he thereon should spin both flax and tow;
But it tormented her both day and night:
Both goodly meede of him it purchase may,
Both which to barre, he with this answere met her;
Both worthie is for to be sewd vnto,
His resolution was both first and last,
That both her Ladie, and her selfe withall,
Of both beloued well, but litle frended;
And then both Knights enuide, & Ladies eke did spight.
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
Both armed Knights, and eke vnarmed rout:
For that they both like race in equall iustice runne.
So meaning to suppresse both forged guile,
Both flames and tempest: with which growen great,
But through great fury both their skill forgot,
Both challenge it with equall greedinesse:
But in reuenge both of her loues distresse,
She with one stroke both head and helmet cleft.
Yet fled she fast, and both them farre outwent,
So both together ylike felly bent,
Against him made againe. So both anon
Of both her foes had seene, and now her frends
Vntill they both doe heare, what she to them will say.
Both to redresse, and both redrest likewise:
Both to redresse, and both redrest likewise:
Witnesse the Paynims both, whom ye may see
He much admired both his heart and hew,
But sith ye please, that both our blames shall die,
So can they both them selues full eath perswade
To faire accordaunce, and both faults to shade,
Both to her selfe, and to her commonweale,
Thus goe they both together to their geare,
Or made them both one masse withouten more remorse.
And backe with both his hands vnto him hayles
That all obedience both to words and deeds
So both for rest there hauing stayd not long,
They both resoluing now to leaue the place,
Both it and all the wealth therein behight
By whose entreatie both they ouercommen,
Thereto both his owne wylie wit, (she sayd)
Both vnassaylable, gaue him great ayde:
So both agreed, to send that mayd afore,
Both ouer rockes, and hilles, and euery place,
Both with bold speaches, which he blazed had,
Which on both sides was then debating hard:
(Both two her paramours, both by her hyred,
(Both two her paramours, both by her hyred,
And both with hope of shadowes vaine inspyred.)
Both doing and receiuing curtesies,
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
Those he deuoures, they say, both flesh and bone:
They both encounter in the middle plaine,
And their sharpe speares doe both together smite
Both through his haberieon, and eke his corse:
And all the people both of towne and land,
He day and night doth ward both far and wide,
Both man and beast doe fly, and succour doe inquyre.
And chaced them both ouer hill and dale:
But dearer then the[m] both, your faith once plighted hold.
But he them ouerthrew both man and horse,
But this same both her selfe, and others eke perplext.
They both arose, and at him loudly cryde,
And foule abusion both his honour blent,
They knew them selues, and both their persons rad:
So both tooke goodly leaue, and parted seuerall.
Both hand and foote vnto a tree was bound:
Did set vppon vs flying both for feare:
Both noble armes and gentle curtesie.
But rudely rowld to ground both man and horse,
For both were wondrous practicke in that play,
And both inflam'd with furious despight:
